Speaker: written by
Dialogue: John Briley

Speaker: manu
Dialogue: Brother -- Bapu is already late for prayers.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Oh, God... oh, God...

Speaker: murrow
Dialogue: ...The object of this massive tribute died as he had always lived -- a private man without wealth, without property, without official title or office...

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Tell me -- do you think about hell?

Speaker: porter
Dialogue: "Hell!"

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: but this man is a Christian and he has written --

Speaker: porter
Dialogue: Excuse me, baas, but how long have you been in South Africa?

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: A -- a week.

Speaker: porter
Dialogue: Well, I don't know how you got a ticket for --

Speaker: conductor
Dialogue: Here -- coolie, just what are you doing in this car?

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Why -- I -- I have a ticket. A First Class ticket.

Speaker: conductor
Dialogue: How did you get hold of it?

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I sent for it in the post. I'm an attorney, and I didn't have time to --

Speaker: european
Dialogue: There are no colored attorneys in South Africa. Go and sit where you belong.

Speaker: porter
Dialogue: I'll take your luggage back, baas.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: No, no -- just a moment, please.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: You see, Mohandas K. Gandhi, Attorney at Law. I am going to Pretoria to conduct a case for an Indian trading firm.

Speaker: european
Dialogue: Didn't you hear me? There are no colored attorneys in South Africa!

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Sir, I was called to the bar in London and enrolled in the High Court of Chancery -- I am therefore an attorney, and since I am -- in your eyes -- colored -- I think we can deduce that there is at least one colored attorney in South Africa.

Speaker: european
Dialogue: Smart bloody kaffir -- throw him out!

Speaker: conductor
Dialogue: You move your damn sammy carcass back to third class or I'll have you thrown off at the next station.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I always go First Class! I have traveled all over England and I've never...

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: But you're a rich man -- why do you put up with it?

Speaker: khan
Dialogue: I'm rich -- but I'm Indian. I therefore do not expect to travel First Class.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: In England, I was a poor student but I --

Speaker: khan
Dialogue: That was England.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: This part of "England's" Empire!

Speaker: singh
Dialogue: Mr. Gandhi, you look at Mr. Khan and see a successful Muslim trader. The South Africans see him simply as an Indian. And the vast majority of Indians -- mostly Hindu like yourself --  were brought here to work the mines and harvest the crops -- and the Europeans don't want them doing anything else.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: But that is very un-Christian.

Speaker: tyeb mohammed
Dialogue: Mr. Gandhi, in this country Indians are not allowed to walk along a pavement with a "Christian"!

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: You mean you employ Mr. Baker as your attorney, but you can't walk down the street with him?

Speaker: khan
Dialogue: I can. But I risk being kicked into the gutter by someone less "holy" than Mr. Baker.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Well, then, it must be fought. We are children of God like everyone else.

Speaker: khan
Dialogue: Allah be praised. And what battalions will you call upon?

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I -- I will write to the press -- here -- and in England.  And I will use the courts.

Speaker: singh
Dialogue: You will make a lot of trouble.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: We are members of the Empire. And we come from an ancient civilization. Why should we not walk on the pavements like other men?

Speaker: khan
Dialogue: I rather like the idea of an Indian barrister in South Africa. I'm sure our community could keep you in work for some time, Mr. Gandhi -- even if you caused a good deal of trouble.  Especially if you caused a good deal of trouble.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: There's the English reporter. I told you he'd come.

Speaker: khan
Dialogue: You also said your article would draw a thousand people.  At least some of the Hindus brought their wives.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: No. I asked my wife to organize that.

Speaker: singh
Dialogue: Some of them are leaving...

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Ladies and Gentlemen, we have asked you to gather here to help us proclaim our right to be treated as equal citizens of the Empire.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: We do not seek conflict. We know the strength of the forces arrayed against us, know that because of them we can only use peaceful means -- but we are determined that justice will be done!

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: The symbol of our status is embodied in this pass -- which we must carry at all times, but no European even has to have.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: And the first step to changing our status is to eliminate this difference between us.

Speaker: khan
Dialogue: You write brilliantly, but you have much to learn about handling men.

Speaker: khan
Dialogue: We do not want to ignite... the fear or hatred of anyone. But we ask you -- Hindu, Muslim and Sikh -- to help us light up the sky... and the minds of the British authorities -- with our defiance of this injustice.

Speaker: khan
Dialogue: We will now burn the passes of our committee and its supporters. We ask you to put your passes on the fire with --

Speaker: police sergeant
Dialogue: Oh, no, you bloody well don't!

Speaker: police sergeant
Dialogue: Those passes are government property! And I will arrest the first man who tries to burn one!

Speaker: police sergeant
Dialogue: Take him away!

Speaker: police sergeant
Dialogue: Now -- are there any more?!

Speaker: police sergeant
Dialogue: You little sammy bastard -- I --

Speaker: police sergeant
Dialogue: You want that kind of trouble -- you can have it!

Speaker: ba
Dialogue: Let me go!

Speaker: sergeant
Dialogue: Stop!

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: You saved the papers.

Speaker: ba
Dialogue: I wish you were still struggling for work in Bombay.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I hated that -- all the pettiness, the little corruptions.  And I was more laughing stock than lawyer.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: But they needed me here. If I'd never been thrown off that train, perhaps no one would ever have needed me.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: "A high court judge has confirmed that Mr. Gandhi would have been within his rights to prosecute for assault since neither he nor Mr. Khan resisted arrest." -- I told you about English law.

Speaker: ba
Dialogue: As I told you about English policemen.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Yes?

Speaker: harilal
Dialogue: We are glad to have you back, Bapu.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: And I am glad to be back.  Come...

Speaker: ba
Dialogue: Be careful!

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Tomorrow I will tell you what it feels like to be a jailbird.

Speaker: ayah
Dialogue: Come. Come.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Just like proper English gentlemen. I'm proud of them.

Speaker: ba
Dialogue: They are boys. -- And they're Indian.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Hm. Will you take this off?  It pinches every time I speak.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Here, you see? Even the South African papers apologize -- "a monstrous attack."

Speaker: ba
Dialogue: Are you sure?

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Yes -- I can't talk like this.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Pull!

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Oww!

Speaker: ba
Dialogue: Mr. Khan said they called you brave.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: If you would let me teach you to read, you could see for yourself.

Speaker: ba
Dialogue: I could have told them you were merely foolish.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: It proves what I told you. If I had prosecuted him as everyone advised -- even you -- they would have hated me -- by showing forgiveness I -- ouch!

Speaker: ba
Dialogue: There...

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: You see there is such a thing as moral force -- and it can be harnessed.

Speaker: ba
Dialogue: Not always. You have told me twice now that you were giving up the pleasures of the flesh.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I am. I am convinced the holy men are right. When you give up, you gain. The simpler your life the better.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I will fast tomorrow -- as a penance.

Speaker: ba
Dialogue: If you enjoy it a great deal you must fast for two days.

Speaker: smuts
Dialogue: Yes -- ?

Speaker: smuts
Dialogue: Did they? Well, they'll find we're a little better prepared this time. Mr. Gandhi will find he's on a long hiding to nothing.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: You'd be Gandhi --  ...I thought you'd be bigger.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I'm sorry.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: I -- I mean it's all right. It doesn't matter.  I'm -- my name is Andrews, Charlie Andrews. I've come from India -- I've read a great deal about you.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Some of it good, I hope.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Would you care to walk?

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: You're a clergyman.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Yes. I've -- I've met some very remarkable people in India... and -- and when I read what you've been doing here, I -- I wanted to help.  Does that surprise you?

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Not anymore.  At first I was amazed... but when you are fighting in a just cause, people seem to pop up -- like you -- right out of the pavement. Even when it is dangerous or --

Speaker: first youth
Dialogue: Hey -- look what's comin'!

Speaker: second youth
Dialogue: A white shepherd leading a brown sammy!

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Perhaps I should --

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Doesn't the New Testament say, "If your enemy strikes you on the right cheek, offer him the left"?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: I think perhaps the phrase was used metaphorically... I don't think our Lord meant --

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I'm not so certain. I have thought about it a great deal. I suspect he meant you must show courage -- be willing to take a blow -- several blows -- to show you will not strike back -- nor will you be turned aside... And when --

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: ...and when you do that it calls upon something in human nature -- something that makes his hate for you diminish and his respect increase. I think Christ grasped that and I -- I have seen it work.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Good morning.

Speaker: first youth
Dialogue: Get off the pavement, you bloody --

Speaker: first youth
Dialogue: Nuthing... nuthing. We were just cleaning up the neighborhood a little.

Speaker: colin's mother
Dialogue: You're already late for work. I thought you'd gone ten minutes ago.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: You'll find there's room for us both.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: That was lucky.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I thought you were a man of God.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: I am. But I'm not so egotistical as to think He plans His day around my dilemmas.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: ...you could call it a "communal farm," I suppose. But we've all come to the same conclusion -- our Gita, the Muslim's Koran or your Bible -- it's always the simple things that catch your breath -- "Love thy neighbor as thyself" --  not always practiced -- but it's something we Hindus could learn a lot from.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: That's the sort of thing you'll be seeking on this "farm"...

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Well, we shall try.

Speaker: sonja
Dialogue: They're going to change the pass laws.

Speaker: second voice
Dialogue: Just one second, sir, please.

Speaker: smuts
Dialogue: But on a short trip, I wouldn't spend too much time on the Indian question, Mr. Walker. It's a tiny factor in South African life.

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: It's news at the moment. I will certainly report on your mines and the economy -- but I would like to meet this Mr. Gandhi.

Speaker: smuts
Dialogue: Of course. We Westerners have a weakness for these -- these spiritually inclined men of India. But as an old lawyer, let me warn you, Mr. Gandhi is as shrewd a man as you will ever meet, however "otherworldly" he may seem. But I'm sure you're enough of a reporter to see that.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: ...so it's not "spiritualism" or "nationalism" -- we're not against anything but the idea that people can't live together.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: You see -- Hindus, Muslims, Sikhs, Jews -- even Christians.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Mr. Walker! Of The New York Times!

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Without a paper -- a journal of some kind -- you cannot unite a community.  You belong to a very important profession.

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: Hm. And what should an "important professional" write about your response to General Smuts's new legislation?

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I don't know... I'm still searching for a "response."

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: You will respect the law.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: There are unjust laws -- as there are unjust men.

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: You're a very small minority to take on the Government -- and the Empire.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: If you are a minority of one, the truth is the truth.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: This is Mr. Kallenbach. He is our chief carpenter -- and also our chief benefactor. He has made this experiment possible.

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: Well, it's quite a place, your "ashram" -- is that right?

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: That's right. The word only means "community." But it could stand for "village"... or the world.

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: You're an ambitious man.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I hope not.

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: They tell me you also take your turn at peeling potatoes and cleaning the "outhouse" -- is that part of the experiment?

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Ba -- we will need another place set for Mr. Walker's driver.

Speaker: ba
Dialogue: I will tell Sora.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: It's one way to learn that each man's labor is as important as another's. In fact when you're doing it, "cleaning the outhouse" seems far more important than the law.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Please come and join us -- you'll need something before your journey back.  Excuse me a moment.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: ba
Dialogue: Sora was sent to tell me I -- I must rake and cover the latrine.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Everyone takes his turn.

Speaker: ba
Dialogue: It is the work of untouchables.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: In this place there are no untouchables -- and no work is beneath any of us!

Speaker: ba
Dialogue: I am your wife.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: All the more reason.

Speaker: ba
Dialogue: As you command.

Speaker: ba
Dialogue: The others may follow you -- but you forget, I knew you when you were a boy!

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: It's not me. It's the principle. And you will do it with joy or not do it at all!

Speaker: ba
Dialogue: Not at all then...

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: All right, go! You don't belong here! Go! Leave the ashram! Get out altogether! We don't want you!

Speaker: ba
Dialogue: Stop it! Stop it! What are you doing!?

Speaker: ba
Dialogue: Where do you expect me to go?

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: What is the matter with me...?

Speaker: ba
Dialogue: You are human -- only human.

Speaker: ba
Dialogue: And it is even harder for those of us who do not even want to be as good as you do.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I apologize...

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I must go back to that reporter.

Speaker: ba
Dialogue: ...And I must rake and cover the latrine.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I want to welcome you all!

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Every one of you.  We -- have -- no -- secrets.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Let us begin by being clear about General Smuts's new law. All Indians must now be fingerprinted -- like criminals. Men and women.  No marriage other than a Christian marriage is considered valid. Under this Act our wives and mothers are whores... And every man here a bastard.

Speaker: khan
Dialogue: He's become quite good at this.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: And a policeman passing an Indian dwelling -- I will not call them homes -- may enter and demand the card or any Indian woman whose dwelling it is.

Speaker: a voice
Dialogue: God damn them!

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Understand! He does not have to stand at the door -- he may enter.

Speaker: merchant
Dialogue: I swear to Allah I will kill the man who offers that insult to my home and my wife!  And let them hang me!

Speaker: tyeb mohammed
Dialogue: I say talk means nothing. Kill a few officials before they disgrace one Indian woman -- then they might think twice about such laws!

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I praise such courage. I need such courage -- because in this cause, I too am prepared to die...  But, my friend, there is no cause for which I am prepared to kill.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I have asked you here tonight because despite all their troops and police, I think there is a way to defeat this law. Whatever they do to us we will attack no one, kill no one... But we will not  give our fingerprints -- not one of us.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: They will imprison us, they will fine us. They will seize our possessions. But they cannot take away our self-respect if we do not give it to them.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I am asking you to fight -- !  To fight against their anger -- not to provoke it!

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: We will not strike a blow -- but we will receive them. And through our pain we will make them see their injustice  They will then have my dead body -- not my obedience.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: We are Hindu and Muslim -- children of God, each of us. Let us take a solemn oath in His name that -- come what may -- we will not submit to this law.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: God save the King!!

Speaker: civilian
Dialogue: These men are contracted laborers. They belong in the mines.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: You have put their comrades in jail. When you free them they will go back to work.

Speaker: civilian
Dialogue: I've warned you.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: We have warned each other.

Speaker: singh
Dialogue: I don't think that is very good.

Speaker: sergeant
Dialogue: At the canter -- for-ward!

Speaker: miner
Dialogue: Down! Down! Everyone lie down!

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Lie down! Lie down!

Speaker: miner
Dialogue: The horses have more mercy than the men.

Speaker: sergeant
Dialogue: You're right!

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Lie down! Lie down!

Speaker: sergeant
Dialogue: Follow me!

Speaker: sergeant
Dialogue: What the hell are we supposed to do now?

Speaker: civilian
Dialogue: Let them march... In our own sweet time, in our own sweet way -- we'll get them.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Some of you may be rejoicing that Mr. Gandhi has at last been put into prison.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: But I would ask you -- assembled here in this house of God -- to recognize that we are witnessing something new, something so unexpected, so unusual that it is not surprising the Government is at a loss. What Mr. Gandhi has forced us to do is ask questions about ourselves.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: As Christians, those are difficult questions to answer. How do we treat men who defy an unjust law -- men who will not fight, but will not comply?

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: They're sparing no one, I see.

Speaker: khan
Dialogue: No. You were the surprise. It's been all over the prison. We thought they'd be too afraid of the English press.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: So did I.

Speaker: khan
Dialogue: -- there's not a trace.

Speaker: khan
Dialogue: I don't know who they've left out there to do the work. There can't be one mine left open. Have they touched the women?

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: My wife publicly defied the law. They've arrested her and four others.

Speaker: khan
Dialogue: Sorry...

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: It's split the Government.

Speaker: khan
Dialogue: Well, that's one victory.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: If we hold firm, it won't be the last.

Speaker: khan
Dialogue: Don't worry -- I've never seen men so determined. You've given them a way to fight... And I don't think --

Speaker: prison officer
Dialogue: Gandhi! I want Gandhi! Which sammy is it?

Speaker: smuts
Dialogue: Ah, Mr. Gandhi. I thought we might have a little talk.

Speaker: smuts
Dialogue: Will you have a glass of sherry?

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Thank you. No.

Speaker: smuts
Dialogue: Perhaps some tea?

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I dined at the prison.

Speaker: smuts
Dialogue: Ahh.

Speaker: smuts
Dialogue: Please -- please do come and sit down. It's prison I wanted to talk to you about.

Speaker: smuts
Dialogue: Mr. Gandhi, I've more or less decided to ask the House to repeal the Act that you have taken such "exception" to.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Well, if you ask, General Smuts, I'm sure it will be done.

Speaker: smuts
Dialogue: Hm. Of course it is not quite that simple.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Somehow I expected not.

Speaker: smuts
Dialogue: I'm glad to hear you say that... very glad. You see if we repeal the Act under pressure  under this kind of pressure it will create a great deal of resentment. Can you understand that?

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Very well.

Speaker: smuts
Dialogue: I think I could guarantee they would recommend the Act be repealed.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I congratulate them.

Speaker: smuts
Dialogue: But they might also recommend that future Indian immigration be severely restricted -- even stopped.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Immigration was not an issue on which we fought. It would be wrong of us to make it one now that we -- we are in a position of advantage.

Speaker: smuts
Dialogue: You're an extraordinary man.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I assure you I feel a very ordinary man at this moment.

Speaker: smuts
Dialogue: I'm ordering the release of all prisoners within the next twenty- four hours. You yourself are free from this moment.

Speaker: smuts
Dialogue: Assuming we are in agreement?

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Yes -- yes. It's just that... in these clothes I'd -- I'd prefer to go by taxi.

Speaker: smuts
Dialogue: All right. Fine.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I'm -- I'm afraid I have no money.

Speaker: smuts
Dialogue: Oh!  I'm awfully sorry.

Speaker: smuts
Dialogue: Daniels, would you lend Mr. Gandhi a shilling for a taxi?

Speaker: daniels
Dialogue: I beg your pardon, sir?

Speaker: smuts
Dialogue: How far will you be going, Mr. Gandhi?

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: but a shilling will do splendidly for the moment.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Thank you.  Thank you both for a very enlightening experience.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I'm obliged, Mr. Daniels, but I will find my own way out.

Speaker: smuts
Dialogue: He's either a great man or a colossal fraud... Either way, I shall be glad to see the last of him.

Speaker: young englishman
Dialogue: By God, he loves it...

Speaker: second englishman
Dialogue: I'm sure he hates it.

Speaker: second englishman
Dialogue: Generals' reputations are being made in France today, fighting on the Western Front. Not as Military Governors in India.

Speaker: second englishman
Dialogue: What the devil's going on back there?

Speaker: young englishman
Dialogue: It must be that Indian that made all that fuss back in Africa. My cabin boy told me he was on board.

Speaker: second englishman
Dialogue: Why haven't we seen him?  Gandhi?

Speaker: young englishman
Dialogue: Yes. That's it. He was traveling Third Class. There he is.

Speaker: young englishman
Dialogue: After he came out of jail he refused to wear European clothes.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: No, no, I haven't "refused"... I -- I simply wanted to dress the way my comrades in prison dressed.

Speaker: english journalist
Dialogue: Will you support the war effort, Mr. Gandhi?

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I -- I have demanded rights as a British citizen, it is therefore my duty to help in the defense of the British Empire.

Speaker: american reporter
Dialogue: What are you going to do now that you're back in India?

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I don't know... I don't know...

Speaker: nehru
Dialogue: Please, Mr. Gandhi.

Speaker: ba
Dialogue: My dignity comes from following my husband.

Speaker: nehru
Dialogue: Just a few words -- then we'll get you to civilization.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I -- I am glad to be home.  I -- I thank you for your greeting.

Speaker: nehru
Dialogue: We'll follow with your wife -- don't worry, everything's arranged.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Who is that young man?

Speaker: patel
Dialogue: That's young Nehru. He's got his father's intellect, his mother's looks and the devil's charm. If they don't ruin him at Cambridge -- Wave! Wave! -- he may amount to something.

Speaker: patel
Dialogue: I must say when I first saw you as a bumbling lawyer here in Bombay I never thought I'd be greeting you as a national hero.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I'm hardly that, Mr. Patel.

Speaker: patel
Dialogue: Oh, yes, you are. It's been two hundred years since an Indian has cocked a snoot at the British Empire and got away with it. And stop calling me Mr. Patel, you're not a junior clerk anymore.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: patel
Dialogue: The new Military Governor of the North West Province was on that ship. Too bad you came back Third Class -- he might have been impressed by a successful barrister who had outmaneuvered General Smuts.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Yes... I'm sure...

Speaker: nehru
Dialogue: Mr. Jinnah, our joint host, member of Congress, and the leader of the Muslim League and Mr. Prakash, who I fear is awaiting trial for sedition and inducement to murder.

Speaker: prakash
Dialogue: I have not actually pulled a trigger, Mr. Gandhi, I have simply written that if an Englishman kills an Indian for disobeying his law, then it is an Indian's duty to kill an Englishman for enforcing his law in a land that is not his.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: It is a clever argument; I am not sure it will produce the end you desire.

Speaker: jinnah
Dialogue: We hope you intend to join us in the struggle for Home Rule, Mr. Gandhi.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: May I? Mohan -- I would like you to meet someone.

Speaker: nehru
Dialogue: He told the press he would support the British in the war.

Speaker: prakash
Dialogue: That's non-violence for you.

Speaker: jinnah
Dialogue: Is he a fool?

Speaker: nehru
Dialogue: I'm not certain... But I wouldn't be surprised.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: I lied to you, Mohan, when I told you I decided to come to South Africa to meet you. Professor Gokhale sent me.

Speaker: gokhale
Dialogue: We're trying to make a nation, Gandhi -- and the British keep trying to break us up into religions and principalities and "provinces." What you were writing in South Africa -- that's what we need here.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I have much to learn about India. And I have to begin my practice again -- one needs money to run a journal.

Speaker: gokhale
Dialogue: Nonsense.  Go on, Charlie. This is Indian talk -- we want none of you imperialists.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: All right -- I'll go and write my report to the Viceroy.

Speaker: gokhale
Dialogue: Go and find a pretty Hindu woman and convert her to Christianity -- that's as much mischief as you're allowed.

Speaker: gokhale
Dialogue: Forget your practice. India has many men with too much wealth -- it is their privilege to nourish the efforts of the few who can raise India from servitude and apathy. I will see to it -- you begin your journal.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I have little to say. India is an "alien" country to me.

Speaker: gokhale
Dialogue: Well, change that. Go and find India. Not what you see here, but the real India. You'll see what needs to be said. What we need to hear.

Speaker: gokhale
Dialogue: When I saw you in that tunic I knew... I knew I could die in peace.  Make India proud of herself.

Speaker: troop leader
Dialogue: Clear the way! Get out of the way!

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: And for the brave terrorists whose patriotism led them to do what was wrong.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: It is not my law, it is the law of creation. We reap what we sow. Out there in the fields -- and in our hearts. Violence sows hatred, and the will to revenge. In them. And in us.

Speaker: patel
Dialogue: I agree with Jinnah. Now that the Americans are in, the war will end soon. The Germans are worn out as it is...  and our first act should be to convene a Congress Party convention and demand independence.

Speaker: jinnah
Dialogue: And we must speak with one voice -- united.

Speaker: patel
Dialogue: Ah -- we should invite Gandhi. What the devil has happened to him anyway?

Speaker: nehru
Dialogue: He's "discovering" India.

Speaker: jinnah
Dialogue: Which is a lot better than causing trouble where it matters. Invite him -- let him say his piece about South Africa -- and then let him slip into oblivion.

Speaker: ba
Dialogue: Please! You're being foolish!

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: There's no room! And the air is lovely.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: No violence, please.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Let me hang on with two hands or I will fall.

Speaker: indian
Dialogue: Englishman Sahib!

Speaker: indian
Dialogue: Come! Come! There is room!

Speaker: first indian
Dialogue: Place the foot on the window.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: What are you doing?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Going nearer to God!

Speaker: ba
Dialogue: Charlie! Be careful!!

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Mohan -- !!

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Let go! You'll kill him!

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Let go! Let go!

Speaker: first indian
Dialogue: You see -- most comfortable.

Speaker: ba
Dialogue: Please, God, no!

Speaker: second indian
Dialogue: Are you Christian, Sahib?

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Yes, yes, I'm a Christian.

Speaker: second indian
Dialogue: She drinks blood.

Speaker: second indian
Dialogue: The blood of Christ -- every Sunday!

Speaker: gandhi's voice
Dialogue: Charlie!!

Speaker: first indian
Dialogue: It's all right, Sahib! Very safe -- bend -- bend!

Speaker: indian's voice
Dialogue: Pray to God, Sahib! Now is when it is best to be Hindu!

Speaker: jinnah
Dialogue: We were asked for toleration. We were asked for patience. Some gave it and some did not. Well, their war is over! And those of us who supported it, and those of us who refused must forget our differences!

Speaker: jinnah
Dialogue: And there can be no excuses from the British now! India wants Home Rule! India demands Home Rule!!

Speaker: patel
Dialogue: And let no one question that Mr. Jinnah speaks not just for the Muslims -- but for all India!

Speaker: patel
Dialogue: And now I'm going to introduce to you a man whose writings we are all becoming familiar with... a man who stood high in the esteem of our beloved Professor Gokhale... a man whose accomplishment in South Africa will always be remembered. Mr. Mohandas Gandhi.

Speaker: patel
Dialogue: Your journal has made a great impact.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I am flattered by Mr. Patel  I would be even more flattered if what he said were true.

Speaker: patel
Dialogue: But it's true! I -- I read it... often.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Since I returned from South Africa, I have traveled over much of India. And I know I could travel many more years and still only see a small part of it.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: ...and yet already I know what we say here means nothing to the masses of our country.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Here we make speeches for each other -- and those English liberal magazines that may grant us a few lines.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: But the people of India are untouched. Their politics are confined to bread and salt.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Illiterate they may be, but they are not blind. They see no reason to give their loyalty to rich and powerful men who simply want to take over the role of the British in the name of freedom.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: This Congress tells the world it represents India. My brothers, India is seven hundred thousand "villages" not a few hundred lawyers in Delhi and Bombay. Until we stand in the fields with the millions who toil each day under the hot sun, we will not represent India -- nor will we ever be able to challenge the British as one nation.

Speaker: nehru
Dialogue: Have you read his magazine?

Speaker: patel
Dialogue: No -- but I think I'm going to.

Speaker: first friend
Dialogue: This can't be the way!

Speaker: second friend
Dialogue: Yes, I'm sure this is the direction India is taking.

Speaker: second friend
Dialogue: To think I almost got excited by Mr. Jinnah when all this was awaiting me.

Speaker: nehru
Dialogue: We're looking for Mr. Gandhi!

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Ah, you'll find him under the tree by the river.  You'd better leave the car -- the ground is rather soft.

Speaker: nehru
Dialogue: Thank you . . .

Speaker: first friend
Dialogue: Come on! I'm anxious to meet this new "force"!

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I try to live like an Indian, as you see... it is stupid of course, because in our country it is the British who decide how an Indian lives -- what he may buy, what he may sell. And from their luxury in the midst of our terrible poverty they instruct us on what is justice and what is sedition.  So it is only natural that our best young minds assume an air of Eastern dignity, while greedily assimilating every Western weakness as quickly as they can acquire it.

Speaker: nehru
Dialogue: If we have Home Rule that will change.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Would you, please?

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: And why should the English grant us Home Rule? Here, we must take the peelings to the goats.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: We only make wild speeches, or perform even wilder acts of terrorism. We've bred an army of anarchists but not one single group that can really fight the British anywhere.

Speaker: nehru
Dialogue: I thought you were against fighting.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Just spread it around -- they like the new peelings mixed with the rotting ones.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Where there is injustice, I've always believed in fighting.  For myself, I have found that we are all such sinners we should leave punishment to God. And if we really want to change things there are better ways of doing it than by derailing trains or slashing someone with a sword.

Speaker: ba
Dialogue: The fire is ready.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: You see, even here we live under tyranny.

Speaker: nehru
Dialogue: I told you...

Speaker: first friend
Dialogue: Hm... but look at him. Some "fighter"! I can see the British shaking now.

Speaker: ba
Dialogue: But it's the ink that is the most diffic --

Speaker: shukla
Dialogue: I am looking for Mr. Gandhi...

Speaker: shukla
Dialogue: ...I've wanted to speak to you for a long time.

Speaker: shukla
Dialogue: ...our crops... we can't sell them... We have no money... but the landlords take the same rent.

Speaker: english captain
Dialogue: Clear the way there! Get out of the way!

Speaker: sergeant putnam
Dialogue: Sir! Up here!

Speaker: english captain
Dialogue: Give me a leg up, will you!

Speaker: english captain
Dialogue: What the hell is it, Sergeant?

Speaker: english captain
Dialogue: Jesus...!

Speaker: english captain
Dialogue: What the hell is going on?

Speaker: sergeant putnam
Dialogue: I don't know, sir. The agent says they got a telegram and it just said, he is coming... and gave the time of the train.

Speaker: english captain
Dialogue: Who the hell is he?

Speaker: sergeant putnam
Dialogue: I don't know, sir.

Speaker: english captain
Dialogue: Who the devil are you?

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: My name is Gandhi. Mohandas K. Gandhi.

Speaker: english captain
Dialogue: Well, whoever you are, we don't want you here. I suggest you get back on that train before it leaves the station.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: They seem to want me.

Speaker: english captain
Dialogue: Now look here. I'll put you under arrest if you'd prefer?

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: On what charge?

Speaker: english captain
Dialogue: I don't want any trouble.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I am an Indian traveling in my own country. I see no reason for trouble.

Speaker: english captain
Dialogue: Well, there'd better not be.

Speaker: meha
Dialogue: For years the landlords have ordered us to grow indigo, for dyeing the cloth. Always they took part of the crop as rent.

Speaker: meha
Dialogue: But now the English factories make cloth for everyone. No one wants our indigo. And the landlords won't take their share. They say we must pay our rent in cash.

Speaker: meha
Dialogue: What we could, we sold... The police have taken the rest. There is no food, we --

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I understand.  The landlords are British?

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: What we can do... we will try to do.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Is all Champaran like this, Shukla?

Speaker: shukla
Dialogue: Yes, Bapu...  The whole province... hundreds -- thousands.

Speaker: charlie's voice
Dialogue: Mohan -- !

Speaker: policeman
Dialogue: Are you Mr. M. K. Gandhi?

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: policeman
Dialogue: I'm sorry but you are under arrest.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I am not sorry at all.

Speaker: batsman
Dialogue: Who did you say would be buying the drinks?

Speaker: batsman
Dialogue: Oh, no --

Speaker: major
Dialogue: ...I've got no idea. All I know is there's a riot or something at Motihari in Champaran, and the whole company is ordered out.

Speaker: a voice
Dialogue: It's two days' march!

Speaker: major
Dialogue: That's why the match is off. It's mostly Muslim territory and the old man's taking no chances.

Speaker: batsman
Dialogue: God, and it's the best innings I've had since Oxford.

Speaker: wicket keeper
Dialogue: India's full of grief, old man.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: I wish to see the prisoner, please.

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: All right, Sergeant.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Charlie--

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: ...Shades of South Africa.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Not quite. They're only "holding me" until the Magistrate's hearing. Then it will be prison.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Did they take your clothes?

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: These are my clothes now.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: You always had a puritanical streak, Mohan.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: If I want to be one with them, I have to live like them.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: I think you do.  But I thank God we all don't.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I'm sure your legs are quite as handsome as mine.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Ah, but my puritanism runs the another way. I'm far too modest for such a display.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Couldn't I be let in with the prisoner? I am a clergyman.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: They're calling you "Bapu." I thought it meant father.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: It does. We must be getting old, Charlie.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: What do you want me to do?

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I think, Charlie, that you can help us most by taking that assignment you've been offered in Fiji.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I have to be sure -- they have to be sure -- that what we do can be done by Indians... alone.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: But you know the strategy. The world is full of people who will despise what's happening here. It is their strength we need. Before you go, you could start us in the right direction.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: I must leave from Calcutta, and soon. You'll have to say goodbye to Ba for me.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: When I get the chance.

Speaker: charlie
Dialogue: Well, I --

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: There are no goodbyes for us, Charlie. Wherever you are, you will always be in my heart...

Speaker: magistrate
Dialogue: I am going to clear the courtroom.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: I'm not sure we'd be able to. And it is a first hearing, it's supposed to be public. And he's a lawyer.

Speaker: magistrate
Dialogue: I don't know where they found the nerve for all this.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: I'm sure I don't either, but the troops won't be here until tomorrow.

Speaker: magistrate
Dialogue: How the press get here before the military?

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: That English clergyman sent a number of telegrams yesterday afternoon. I understand one of them even went to the Viceroy.

Speaker: magistrate
Dialogue: You have been ordered out of the province on the grounds of disturbing the peace.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: With respect, I refuse to go.

Speaker: magistrate
Dialogue: Do you want to go to jail?

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: As you wish.

Speaker: magistrate
Dialogue: All right. I will release you on bail of one hundred rupees until I reach a sentence.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I refuse to pay one hundred rupees.

Speaker: magistrate
Dialogue: Then I -- I will grant release without bail -- until I reach a decision.

Speaker: a voice
Dialogue: Gandhiji! -- Gandhiji! Mr. Gandhi!

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Indeed.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I want to document, coldly, rationally, what is being done here. It may take months -- many, many months.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: You will have to live with the peasants.  Hmm.

Speaker: sir george
Dialogue: I don't know what this country is coming to!

Speaker: sir edward
Dialogue: But good God, man, you yourself raised the rent simply to finance a hunting expedition!

Speaker: sir edward
Dialogue: And some of these others --  beatings, illegal seizures, demanding services without pay, even refusing them water! In India!...

Speaker: sir george
Dialogue: Nobody knows what it is to try to get these people to work!

Speaker: sir edward
Dialogue: Well, you've make this half-naked whatever-he-is into an international hero.

Speaker: sir edward
Dialogue: "One lone man marching dusty roads armed only with honesty and a bamboo shaft doing battle with the British Empire."  At home children are writing "essays" about him.

Speaker: sir edward
Dialogue: I couldn't take another two years of him to save my life.

Speaker: sir george
Dialogue: What do they want?

Speaker: personal secretary
Dialogue: They are to be free to grow crops of their own choice. A commission -- part Indian -- to hear grievances.

Speaker: sir george
Dialogue: That would satisfy him?...

Speaker: sir edward
Dialogue: And His Majesty's Government. It only needs your signature for the landlords.

Speaker: sir george
Dialogue: It will be worth it to see the back of him.  We're too damn liberal.

Speaker: sir edward
Dialogue: Perhaps. But at least all this has made the Government see some sense about what men like Mr. Gandhi should be allowed, and what they should be denied.

Speaker: sir edward
Dialogue: Things are going to change.

Speaker: jinnah
Dialogue: Where is Mr. Gandhi?

Speaker: chauffeur
Dialogue: He said he preferred to walk, sir. I followed him most of the way. He's just turned the corner.

Speaker: jinnah
Dialogue: The Prophet give me patience.

Speaker: chauffeur
Dialogue: He came Third Class.

Speaker: jinnah
Dialogue: My house is honored.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: and his interest is in flowers. I presumed to tell him he could wander your gardens while we talked.

Speaker: jinnah
Dialogue: I'll send my gardener. I'm sure you'll have much to discuss.

Speaker: jinnah
Dialogue: Gentlemen -- the hero of Champaran.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Only the stubborn man of Champaran.

Speaker: jinnah
Dialogue: Mr. Patel you know.  Mr. Maulana Azad -- a fellow Muslim... recently released from prison.

Speaker: jinnah
Dialogue: Mr. Kripalani.  And of course you know Mr. Nehru.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I am beginning to know Mr. Nehru.

Speaker: patel
Dialogue: Well, I've called you here because I've had a chance to see the new legislation. It's exactly what was rumored. Arrest without warrant. Automatic imprisonment for possession of materials considered seditious...

Speaker: patel
Dialogue: Your writings are specifically listed.

Speaker: kripalani
Dialogue: So much for helping them in the Great War...

Speaker: jinnah
Dialogue: There is only one answer to that. Direct action -- on a scale they can never handle!

Speaker: nehru
Dialogue: I don't think so.

Speaker: nehru
Dialogue: Terrorism would only justify their repression. And what kinds of leaders would it throw up? Are they likely to be the men we would want at the head of our country?

Speaker: nehru
Dialogue: I've been catching up on my reading.

Speaker: jinnah
Dialogue: I too have read Mr. Gandhi's writings, but I'd rather be ruled by an Indian terrorist than an English one. And I don't want to submit to that kind of law.

Speaker: patel
Dialogue: I must say, Panditji, it seems to me it's gone beyond remedies like passive resistance.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: If I may -- I, for one, have never advocated passive anything.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I am with Mr. Jinnah. We must never submit to such laws -- ever. And I think our resistance must be active and provocative.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I want to embarrass all those who wish to treat us as slaves. All of them.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Forgive my stupid illustration. But I want to change their minds -- not kill them for weaknesses we all possess.

Speaker: azad
Dialogue: And what "resistance" would you offer?

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: The law is due to take effect from April sixth. I want to call on the nation to make that a day of prayer and fasting.

Speaker: jinnah
Dialogue: You mean a general strike?

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I mean a day of prayer and fasting. But of course no work could be done -- no buses, no trains, no factories, no administration. The country would stop.

Speaker: patel
Dialogue: My God, it would terrify them...

Speaker: azad
Dialogue: Three hundred fifty million people at prayer. Even the English newspapers would have to report that. And explain why.

Speaker: kripalani
Dialogue: But could we get people to do it?

Speaker: nehru
Dialogue: They are calling you Mahatma -- the Great Soul.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Fortunately such news comes very slowly where I live.

Speaker: nehru
Dialogue: I think if we all worked to publicize it... all of the Congress... every avenue we know.

Speaker: jinnah
Dialogue: Perhaps I should have stayed in the garden and talked about the flowers.

Speaker: adc
Dialogue: Sir -- it's Mr. Kinnoch.

Speaker: chelmsford
Dialogue: Yes?

Speaker: kinnoch
Dialogue: There's not even any civilian staff here, sir... Everything has stopped.

Speaker: chelmsford
Dialogue: Is it simply Delhi and Bombay?

Speaker: kinnoch
Dialogue: No, sir -- Karachi, Calcutta, Madras, Bangalore. It's, it's total.

Speaker: kinnoch
Dialogue: The Army had to take over the telegraph or we'd be cut off from the world.

Speaker: chelmsford
Dialogue: I can't believe it...

Speaker: kinnoch
Dialogue: He's going to sell his own paper tomorrow in Bombay. They've called for a parade -- on Victoria Road.

Speaker: chelmsford
Dialogue: Arrest him!

Speaker: nehru
Dialogue: Bapu...

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: You too...

Speaker: nehru
Dialogue: It seems less formal than "Mahatma."

Speaker: nehru
Dialogue: Since your arrest the riots have hardly stopped. Not big --; but they keep breaking out. I run to stop them... and Patel and Kripalani -- they are never at rest. But some English civilians have been killed, and the Army is attacking crowds with clubs -- and sometimes worse.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Maybe I'm wrong... maybe we're not ready yet. In South Africa the numbers were small...

Speaker: nehru
Dialogue: The Government's afraid, and they don't know what to do. But they're more afraid of terrorists than of you. The Viceroy has agreed to your release if you will speak for non- violence.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I've never spoken for anything else.

Speaker: speaker
Dialogue: ...England is so powerful -- its army and its navy, all its modern weapons -- but when a great power like that strikes defenseless people it shows it brutality, its own weakness! Especially when those people do not strike back.  That is why the Mahatma begs us to take the course of non-violence!

Speaker: speaker
Dialogue: ...If we riot, if we fight back, we become the vandals and they become the law! If we bear their blows, they are the vandals -- God and His law are on our...  side.

Speaker: speaker
Dialogue: ...We must have the courage to take their anger...

Speaker: dyer
Dialogue: Port arms, Sergeant Major.

Speaker: dyer
Dialogue: Load.

Speaker: speaker
Dialogue: ...Our pain will be our victory.

Speaker: adc
Dialogue: Do we issue a warning, sir?

Speaker: dyer
Dialogue: They've had their warning -- no meetings.

Speaker: dyer
Dialogue: Sergeant Major --

Speaker: sergeant major
Dialogue: Take aim!

Speaker: dyer
Dialogue: Fire!

Speaker: sergeant major
Dialogue: Reload!

Speaker: dyer
Dialogue: Take your time. Take your time.

Speaker: dyer
Dialogue: Corporal!

Speaker: corporal
Dialogue: Sir!

Speaker: dyer
Dialogue: Over there.

Speaker: corporal
Dialogue: Sir.

Speaker: advocate
Dialogue: General Dyer, is it correct that you ordered your troops to fire at the thickest part of the crowd?

Speaker: dyer
Dialogue: That is so.

Speaker: advocate
Dialogue: One thousand five hundred and sixteen casualties with one thousand six hundred and fifty bullets.

Speaker: dyer
Dialogue: My intention was to inflict a lesson that would have an impact throughout all India.

Speaker: indian barrister
Dialogue: General, had you been able to take in the armored car, would you have opened fire with the machine gun?

Speaker: dyer
Dialogue: I think, probably -- yes.

Speaker: hunter
Dialogue: General, did you realize there were children -- and women -- in the crowd?

Speaker: dyer
Dialogue: I did.

Speaker: advocate
Dialogue: But that was irrelevant to the point you were making?

Speaker: dyer
Dialogue: That is correct.

Speaker: advocate
Dialogue: Could I ask you what provision you made for the wounded?

Speaker: dyer
Dialogue: I was ready to help any who applied.

Speaker: advocate
Dialogue: General... how does a child shot with a 3-0-3 Enfield "apply" for help?

Speaker: chelmsford
Dialogue: You must understand, gentlemen, that His Majesty's Government -- and the British people -- repudiate both the massacre and the philosophy that prompted it.

Speaker: chelmsford
Dialogue: What I would like to do is to come to some compromise over the new civil legis --

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: If you will excuse me, Your Excellency, it is our view that matters have gone beyond "legislation."

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: We think it is time you recognized that you are masters in someone else's home.  Despite the best intentions of the best of you, you must, in the nature of things, humiliate us to control us. General Dyer is but an extreme example of the principle. It is time you left.

Speaker: kinnoch
Dialogue: With respect, Mr. Gandhi, without British administration, this country would be reduced to chaos.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Mr. Kinnoch, I beg you to accept that there is no people on earth who would not prefer their own bad government to the "good" government of an alien power.

Speaker: brigadier
Dialogue: My dear sir -- India is British! We're hardly an alien power!

Speaker: chelmsford
Dialogue: Even if His Majesty could waive all other considerations, he has a duty to the millions of his Muslim subjects who are a minority in this realm. And experience has taught that his troops and his administration are essential in order to keep the peace.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: All nations contain religious minorities. Like other countries, ours will have its problems.  But they will be ours -- not yours.

Speaker: general
Dialogue: And how do you propose to make them yours? You don't think we're just going to walk out of India.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Yes... in the end you will walk out. Because one hundred thousand Englishmen simply cannot control three hundred fifty million Indians if the Indians refuse to co-operate. And that is what we intend to achieve -- peaceful, non-violent, non-co- operation.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Until you yourself see the wisdom of leaving... your Excellency.

Speaker: general
Dialogue: "You don't just expect us to walk out?" "Yes."

Speaker: brigadier
Dialogue: Extraordinary little man! "Nonviolent, non-co-operation" -- for a moment I almost thought they were actually going to do something.

Speaker: chelmsford
Dialogue: Yes -- but it would be wise to be very cautious for a time. The Anti- Terrorist Act will remain on the statutes, but on no account is Gandhi to be arrested. Whatever mischief he causes, I have no intention of making a martyr of him.

Speaker: ba
Dialogue: ...but now something worse is happening. When Gandhiji and I were growing up, women wove their own cloth. But now there are millions who have no work because those who can buy all they need from England. I say with Gandhiji, there is no beauty in the finest cloth if it makes hunger and unhappiness.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: My message tonight is the message I have given to your brothers everywhere. To gain independence we must prove worthy of it.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: There must be Hindu-Muslim unity -- always.  Secondly, no Indian must be treated as the English treat us so we must remove untouchability from our lives, and from our hearts.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Third -- we must defy the British.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Not with violence that will inflame their will, but with firmness that will open their eyes.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: English factories make the cloth -- that makes our poverty.  All those who wish to make the English see, bring me the cloth from Manchester and Leeds that you wear tonight, and we will light a fire that will be seen in Delhi -- and London!

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: And if, like me, you are left with only one piece of homespun -- wear it with dignity!

Speaker: patel
Dialogue: Excuse me -- just let me get out of your way, please.  No, thank you, I'll manage.

Speaker: patel
Dialogue: No, no -- don't destroy my good intentions. I'm feeling guilty about traveling Second Class.

Speaker: kallenbach
Dialogue: I do it as a friend -- and admirer -- not a servant.

Speaker: patel
Dialogue: Ah, in that case!

Speaker: patel
Dialogue: Maulana is made of sterner stuff. Our trains met in Bombay, but he's back there in that lot somewhere.

Speaker: patel
Dialogue: When I think what our "beloved Mahatma" asks, I don't know how he ever got such a hold over us. Is he back?

Speaker: kallenbach
Dialogue: Yes. Now that things are moving he's going to write and only take part when it's necessary.

Speaker: azad
Dialogue: It was a Hindu child and it tried to wet on me.

Speaker: patel
Dialogue: Of course. A Muslim beef eater -- I'm only surprised he missed.

Speaker: azad
Dialogue: He was a she.

Speaker: patel
Dialogue: Ah, that explains it.  Well, do I carry your luggage as penance or --

Speaker: kallenbach
Dialogue: There's another passenger -- a Miss Slade.  She's been corresponding with him for a year.

Speaker: patel
Dialogue: And what does the daughter of an English admiral propose to do in an ashram -- sink us?

Speaker: azad
Dialogue: From the looks of the luggage, yes.

Speaker: kallenbach
Dialogue: She wants to make her home with us -- and Gandhiji has agreed.

Speaker: mirabehn
Dialogue: You'd be Mr. Kallenbach.

Speaker: kallenbach
Dialogue: ...And you would be Miss Slade.

Speaker: mirabehn
Dialogue: I prefer the name Gandhiji has given me -- Mirabehn.

Speaker: kallenbach
Dialogue: It was a gift and it only worked a few weeks, but when Gandhi came home he struck on this idea. He calls it his ox-Ford. Comfortable -- and yet more our pace.

Speaker: mirabehn
Dialogue: Might Mr. Nehru be there too?

Speaker: patel
Dialogue: The irresponsible young Nehru is in prison -- again. Though there is a rumor that under pressure from your country, they will let him out -- again.

Speaker: mirabehn
Dialogue: You can't know how closely we follow your struggle --  how many in England admired what you did in Bardoli. It must have taken enormous courage.

Speaker: patel
Dialogue: Well, in this country one must decide if one is more afraid of the government or Gandhi.  For us, it's Gandhi.

Speaker: mirabehn
Dialogue: And you're German...

Speaker: kallenbach
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: mirabehn
Dialogue: And do you feel Indian?

Speaker: kallenbach
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: mirabehn
Dialogue: But you've been with him so long -- why?

Speaker: kallenbach
Dialogue: ...I'd come to believe I would never meet a truly honest man. And then I met one.

Speaker: ba
Dialogue: Stop -- stop...

Speaker: ba
Dialogue: God gave you ten thumbs.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Eleven.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Sardar...

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: What you've done is a miracle. You have made all India proud.

Speaker: patel
Dialogue: It must have been the only Non-violent campaign ever led by a man who wanted to kill everybody every day.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: The secret is mastering the urge.

Speaker: azad
Dialogue: He came Second Class.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Well, we can't expect miracles all the time.  Your news I understand is not so good.

Speaker: azad
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Come, come -- you will be my daughter...

Speaker: azad
Dialogue: ...but then some rioting broke out between Hindus and Muslims -- violent, terrible...

Speaker: azad
Dialogue: Whether it was provoked...  Some of the things the military have done...

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Is the campaign weakening?

Speaker: azad
Dialogue: The marches and protests are bigger if anything but with the censorship here  they know more in England than we do, and it saps the courage to think you may be suffering alone.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: They are not alone. And martial law only shows how desperate the British are.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Is that homespun? Or cotton from Leeds?

Speaker: mirabehn
Dialogue: I -- I sent for it, from here. I dyed it myself.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: What do the workers in England make of what we're doing? It must have produced hardship.

Speaker: mirabehn
Dialogue: It has. But you'd be surprised. They understand -- they really do. It's not the workers you have to worry about.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Good.  Ba will have to teach you to spin too.

Speaker: mirabehn
Dialogue: I would rather march.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: First spin. Let the others march for a time.

Speaker: ba
Dialogue: First lesson: To march, wear shoes, to spin, do not.

Speaker: ba
Dialogue: I'll teach you all our foolishness, and you must teach me yours.

Speaker: marchers
Dialogue: Home Rule! Long live Gandhi! Buy Indian! Long live Gandhi!

Speaker: policeman
Dialogue: I'll stuff your damn mouth with it!

Speaker: second marcher
Dialogue: Leave him alone -- he wasn't harming you!

Speaker: policeman
Dialogue: Hey --

Speaker: patel's voice
Dialogue: That's one bit of news they haven't censored.

Speaker: jinnah's voice
Dialogue: Oh, it's all over the world...  India's "non-violence."

Speaker: nehru
Dialogue: What can we do?

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: We must end the campaign.

Speaker: jinnah
Dialogue: After what they did at the massacre -- it's only an eye for an eye.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: We must stop.

Speaker: patel
Dialogue: Gandhiji -- do you know the sacrifices people have made?

Speaker: jinnah
Dialogue: We would never get the same commitment again -- ever.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: If we obtain our freedom by murder and bloodshed I want no part of it.

Speaker: nehru
Dialogue: It was one incident.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Tell that to the families of the policemen who died.

Speaker: nehru
Dialogue: Bapu -- the whole nation is marching. They wouldn't stop, even if we asked them to.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I will ask. And I will fast as penance for my part in arousing such emotions -- and I will not stop until they stop.

Speaker: jinnah
Dialogue: God! You can be sure the British won't censor that! They'll put it on every street corner.

Speaker: nehru
Dialogue: But -- but Gandhiji people are aroused... they won't stop.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: If I die, perhaps they will...

Speaker: ba
Dialogue: I must get ready for evening prayers. Mirabehn is here.

Speaker: mirabehn
Dialogue: I've brought your drinking water. May I turn you?

Speaker: mirabehn
Dialogue: There is a little lemon juice in it. That is all.

Speaker: mirabehn
Dialogue: Herman has gone to meet Pandit Nehru -- there was a telegram. Almost everywhere it has stopped.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: When it is everywhere, then my prayers will be answered.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Do you find me stubborn?

Speaker: mirabehn
Dialogue: I don't know... I know you are right. I don't know that this is right.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: When I despair, I remember that all through history the way of truth and love has always won.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: There have been tyrants and murderers, and for a time they can seem invincible. But in the end they always fall. Think of it -- always... When you are in doubt that that is God's way, the way the world is meant to be... think of that.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: And now -- could I have another feast of lemon juice?

Speaker: mirabehn
Dialogue: Panditji -- come in.

Speaker: nehru
Dialogue: Jinnah, Patel, all of Congress has called for the end of non-co- operation. There's not been one demonstration. All over India people are praying that you will end the fast. They're walking in the streets, offering garlands to the police -- and to British soldiers.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Perhaps -- perhaps I have overdone it.

Speaker: little boy
Dialogue: Good morning, Bapu!

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Good morning.  Don't let her go. If she bumps me I am done for.

Speaker: little boy
Dialogue: Don't worry. I milk her every day, she's not --

Speaker: police superintendent
Dialogue: Sedition.

Speaker: nehru
Dialogue: You can't be serious! This man has just stopped a revolution!

Speaker: police superintendent
Dialogue: That's as may be. I only know what I am charged to perform.

Speaker: nehru
Dialogue: I don't believe it -- even the British can't be that stupid!

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Panditji -- please, help me.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: You must help Herman -- and Ba.  I have been on many trips -- it is just another trip.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I am at your command.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: If there is one protest -- one riot -- a disgrace of any kind, I will fast again.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I know India is not ready for my kind of independence. If I am sent to jail, perhaps that is the best protest our country can make at this time. And if it helps India, I have never refused to take His Majesty's hospitality.

Speaker: clerk
Dialogue: Call the prisoner to the bar.

Speaker: advocate general
Dialogue: ..."Non-co-operation has one aim: the overthrow of the Government. Sedition must become our creed. We must give no quarter, nor can we expect any."  Signed M. K. Gandhi, in your journal Young India, dated twenty-second March of this year. Do you deny writing it?

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Not at all.  And I will save the Court's time, M'Lord, by stating under oath that to this day I believe non-co-operation with evil is a duty. And that British rule of India is evil.

Speaker: advocate general
Dialogue: The Prosecution rests, M'Lord.

Speaker: judge broomfield
Dialogue: I take it you will conduct your own defense, Mr. Gandhi.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I have no defense, My Lord. I am guilty as charged.  And if you truly believe in the system of law you administer in my country, you must inflict on me the severest penalty possible.

Speaker: judge broomfield
Dialogue: It is impossible for me to ignore that you are in a different category from any person I have ever tried, or am likely to try.

Speaker: judge broomfield
Dialogue: It is nevertheless my duty to sentence you -- to six years' imprisonment.

Speaker: judge broomfield
Dialogue: If however His Majesty's Government could -- at some later date -- see fit to reduce that term, no one would be better pleased than I.

Speaker: collins
Dialogue: Well, he certainly wasn't forgotten! And as soon as he got out he was back tramping the country, preaching non-violence and demanding a free India. Everybody knows another showdown's coming -- but when, and over what --

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: Well, I read you account of that crowd in Calcutta and that he was twisting the Lion's tail again...

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: ...and I knew something had to give. And I was determined to be here when it did.

Speaker: collins
Dialogue: How does a reporter in Central America learn that Gandhi was born in Porbandar anyway?

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: Oh, I've been a Gandhi buff for a long time.

Speaker: collins
Dialogue: He certainly makes good copy.  The other day Winston Churchill called him "that half-naked Indian fakir."

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: I met him once.

Speaker: collins
Dialogue: You mean Gandhi?

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: long time ago.

Speaker: collins
Dialogue: What was he like?

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: Lots of hair... and a little like a college freshman -- trying to figure everything out.

Speaker: collins
Dialogue: Well, he must've found some of the answers...

Speaker: ba
Dialogue: "In every worthy wish of yours, I shall be your helpmate."

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: "Take a fourth step, that we may be ever full of joy."

Speaker: ba
Dialogue: "I will ever live devoted to you, speaking words of love and praying for your happiness."

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: "Take a fifth step, that we may serve the people."

Speaker: ba
Dialogue: "I will follow close behind you and help to serve the people."

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: "Take a sixth step, that we may follow our vows in life."

Speaker: ba
Dialogue: "I will follow you in all our vows and duties."

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: "Take the seventh step, that we may ever live as friends."

Speaker: ba
Dialogue: "You are my best friend... my highest guru, and my sovereign lord."

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Then I put a sweetened wheat cake in her mouth.

Speaker: ba
Dialogue: And I put a sweetened wheat cake in his mouth.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: And with that we were pronounced man and wife.  We were both thirteen...

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: It's beautiful.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Even as a boy I thought so.

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: Trying to keep track of you is making me change all my sleeping habits.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: And you've come all this way because you think something is going to happen?

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: Hm.  Is it?

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Perhaps. I've come here to think about it.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Do you remember much of South Africa?

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: A great deal.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I've traveled so far -- and thought so much.  The temple where you were yesterday is of my family's sect, the Pranami. It was Hindu of course but the priests used to read from the Muslim Koran and the Hindu Gita, moving from one to the other as though it mattered not at all which book was read as long as God was worshipped.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: When I was a boy I used to sing a song in that temple: "A true disciple knows another's woes as his own. He bows to all and despises none... Earthly possessions hold him not." Like all boys I said the words, not thinking of what they meant or how they might be influencing me.  I've traveled so far... and all I've done is come back home.

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: You know what you're going to do.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: It would have been very uncivil of me to let you make such a long trip for nothing.

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: Where are you going?

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I'm going back to the ashram  and then I'm going to prove to the new Viceroy that the King's writ no longer runs in India!

Speaker: irwin
Dialogue: Salt?

Speaker: principal secretary
Dialogue: Yes, sir. He is going to march to the sea and make salt.

Speaker: irwin
Dialogue: All right -- he's breaking the law. What will he be depriving us of, two rupees of salt tax?

Speaker: principal secretary
Dialogue: It's not a serious attack on the revenue, sir. Its primary importance is symbolic.

Speaker: irwin
Dialogue: Don't patronize me, Charles.

Speaker: principal secretary
Dialogue: No, sir. I -- in this climate, sir, nothing lives without water -- or salt. Our absolute control of it is a control on the pulse of India.

Speaker: irwin
Dialogue: And that's the basis of this "Declaration of Independence"?

Speaker: general
Dialogue: I say ignore it. Let them raise their damn flags, let him make his salt. It's only symbolic if we choose to make it so.

Speaker: principal secretary
Dialogue: He's going to arrive at the sea on the anniversary of the massacre at Amritsar.

Speaker: irwin
Dialogue: General Edgar is right -- ignore it. Mr. Gandhi will find it's going to take a great deal more than a pinch of salt to bring down the British Empire.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: ...the real test will come if I am arrested. If there is violence we lose all our moral advantage. This time it mustn't happen.

Speaker: nehru
Dialogue: We're not beginners anymore. We've been trained by a strict sergeant major.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: If I'm taken, Maulana is to lead the march. If he is arrested, Patel, then Kripalani, then yourself.

Speaker: ba
Dialogue: You should be relaxing.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I'm sure I'm fit for at least five hundred miles.

Speaker: mirabehn
Dialogue: You should ride the pony. It is not necessary to walk to prove the point.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I have two of them bossing me now.

Speaker: nehru
Dialogue: We must get these to the printer.  I know it will succeed. Even my mother is prepared to march.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: And Jinnah?

Speaker: nehru
Dialogue: He's waiting. He's not prepared to accept it will mean as much as you think.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Wait and see... wait and see...

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: You've done me a great service.

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: It would have been uncivil of me to have let you make such a long trip for nothing.

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: Is it over if they arrest you now?

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Not if they arrest me -- or a thousand -- or ten thousand.  It is not only generals who know how to plan campaigns.

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: What if they don't arrest you? What if they don't react at all?

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Do you still have your notebook?  The function of a civil resister is to provoke response. And we will continue to provoke until they respond, or they change the law. They are not in control -- we are. That is the strength of civil resistance.

Speaker: collins
Dialogue: What'd he say?

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: He said he's in charge...

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Are you going to walk all the way?

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: My name is Walk-er. And I intend to report it the way it is.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: "My name is Walk-er"...

Speaker: student leader
Dialogue: We've come to join the march. What do we do?

Speaker: pyarelal
Dialogue: Find a place to sleep.

Speaker: brigadier
Dialogue: We're being made fools of around the world!

Speaker: general
Dialogue: Isn't there any instruction from London?

Speaker: irwin
Dialogue: We're required to stop it.  I don't care if we fill the jails, stop it. Arrest anyone, any rank -- except Gandhi. We'll cut his strength from under him. And then we'll deal with the Mahatma.

Speaker: british subaltern
Dialogue: Oh, my God!

Speaker: subaltern
Dialogue: Right -- jump to it -- clear this beach!

Speaker: nehru
Dialogue: No violence, Zia!

Speaker: nehru
Dialogue: ...no violence.

Speaker: sergeant
Dialogue: You're Nehru --

Speaker: nehru
Dialogue: I'm an illegal trader in salt.

Speaker: irwin
Dialogue: Who's leading them?

Speaker: principal secretary
Dialogue: Has there been any violence?

Speaker: irwin
Dialogue: I believe the question was intended to discover if there was any violence of their side.

Speaker: principal secretary
Dialogue: Perhaps if we arrested Gandhi, it might --

Speaker: irwin
Dialogue: He's addressed this letter directly to you, has he?

Speaker: irwin
Dialogue: Thank him for his letter, and put him in jail.

Speaker: irwin
Dialogue: And Fields, keep that salt works open.

Speaker: azad
Dialogue: I would like admission to the Works.

Speaker: azad
Dialogue: Last night they took Gandhiji from us. They expect us to lose heart or to fight back. We will not lose heart, we will not fight back. In his name we will be beaten. As he has taught us, we will not raise a hand. "Long live Mahatma Gandhi!"

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: Ed! Okay -- yeah -- right.

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: "They walked, with heads up, without music, or cheering, or any hope of escape from injury or death."  "It went on and on and on. Women carried the wounded bodies from the ditch until they dropped from exhaustion. But still it went on."

Speaker: walker
Dialogue: "Whatever moral ascendance the West held was lost today. India is free for she has taken all that steel and cruelty can give, and she has neither cringed nor retreated."  "In the words of his followers, 'Long live Mahatma Gandhi.' "

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I am aware that I must have given you much cause for irritation, your Excellency. I hope it will not stand between us as men.

Speaker: irwin
Dialogue: Mr. Gandhi, I have instructions to request your attendance at an All- Government Conference in London to discuss -- to discuss the possible Independence of India.

Speaker: macdonald
Dialogue: I think our first duty is to recognize that there is not one India, but several: a Hindu India, a Muslim India, and India of Princely States. And all these must be respected -- and cared for -- not just one.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Do I speak into that?

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Are they ready? Do I start?

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I am glad to speak to America where so many friends exist that I know only in my heart.

Speaker: gandhi's voice
Dialogue: I think your interest and the world's has fallen on India, not only because we are struggling for freedom, but because the way we are doing so is unique as far as history shows us. Here in Europe mighty nations are, it seems, already contemplating another war, though I think they, and all the world, are sick to death of bloodspilling. All of us are seeking a way out, and I flatter myself that perhaps the ancient land of India will offer such a way. If we are to make progress we must not repeat history, but make history. And I myself will die before I betray our belief that love is a stronger weapon than hate.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: It is only a sprain. Take her to the river, and we'll make a mud-pack for her. Go -- I won't be long.

Speaker: jinnah
Dialogue: So the truth is, after all your travels, all your efforts, they've stopped the campaign and sent you home empty-handed.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: They are only clinging to old dreams  and how.

Speaker: nehru
Dialogue: I say when is now -- and we will determine how.

Speaker: jinnah
Dialogue: Precisely.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: They are preparing for war. I will not support it, but I do not intend to take advantage of their danger.

Speaker: patel
Dialogue: That's when you take advantage.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: No. That is just another way of striking back. We have come a long way together with the British. When they leave we want to see them off as friends.  And now, if you'll excuse me, there is something I must attend to.

Speaker: nehru
Dialogue: "Mud packs."

Speaker: british colonel
Dialogue: Mr. Gandhi -- sir.

Speaker: british colonel
Dialogue: I have instructions to inquire as to the subject of your speech tonight.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: The value of goat's milk in daily diet.  But you can be sure I will also speak against war.

Speaker: british colonel
Dialogue: I'm sorry, sir. That can't be allowed.

Speaker: adjutant
Dialogue: It's all right, Mrs. Gandhi. I have orders to return with you and your companion to the Mahatma's ashram.

Speaker: ba
Dialogue: If you take my husband, I intend to speak in his place.

Speaker: lieutenant
Dialogue: It was the Aga Khan's palace, but they've turned it into a prison.

Speaker: lieutenant
Dialogue: They've got most of the leading Congress politicians in this one. But Nehru and some others are over in Dehra Dun. Your timing's pretty lucky. They had your Mr. Gandhi cut off from the press but last month his personal secretary died and they've let up on the restrictions.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Yes, I have heard of Life Magazine.  I have even heard of Margaret Bourke- White. But I don't know why either should be interested in an old man sitting in prison when the world is blowing itself to pieces.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Ah, but for me that's not much of an accomplishment.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: No -- prison is rather agreeable to me, and there is no doubt that after the war, independence will come. My only worry is what shape it will take. Jinnah has --

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: That I find hard to bear -- even in prison.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I have a friend who keeps telling me how much it costs him to keep me in poverty.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: It will not necessarily be "progress" for India if she simply imports the unhappiness of the West.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: What you cannot do is accept injustice. From Hitler -- or anyone. You must make the injustice visible -- be prepared to die like a soldier to do so.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: No. That is what you get for distracting me.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: I expect you to show as much patience as I am now.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Every enemy is a human being -- even the worst of them. And he believes he is right and you are a beast.  And if you beat him over the head you will only convince him. But you suffer, to show him that he is wrong, your sacrifice creates an atmosphere of understanding -- if not with him, then in the hearts of the rest of the community on whom he depends.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: If you are right, you will win -- after much pain.  If you are wrong, well, then, only you will suffer the blows.

Speaker: ba
Dialogue: ...not at all. Bapu has always said there were two kinds of slavery in India -- one for women, one for the untouchables -- and he has always fought against both.

Speaker: ba
Dialogue: Yes... but we see each other in the day.

Speaker: ba
Dialogue: In Hindu philosophy the way to God is to free yourself of possessions -- and the passions that inflame to anger and jealousy.  Bapu has always struggled to find the way to God.

Speaker: ba
Dialogue: Four times he tried -- and failed.  But then he took a solemn vow...

Speaker: ba
Dialogue: Not yet.

Speaker: major
Dialogue: I've got permission to move her -- he can go too.

Speaker: doctor
Dialogue: She's had a coronary throm -- a serious heart failure. She wouldn't survive a trip. It's best to leave her -- and hope.

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: It is time for my walk -- I won't be long.

Speaker: mountbatten
Dialogue: We have come to crown victory with friendship -- to assist at the birth of an independent India and to welcome her as an equal member in the British Commonwealth of Nations.  I am here to see that I am the last British Viceroy ever to have the honor of such a reception.

Speaker: jinnah
Dialogue: I don't give a damn for the independence of India! I am concerned about the slavery of Muslims!

Speaker: jinnah
Dialogue: I will not sit by to see the mastery of the British replaced by the mastery of the Hindus!

Speaker: gandhi
Dialogue: Muslim and Hindu are the right and left eye of India. No one will be slave, no one master.

Speaker: jinnah
Dialogue: The world is not made of Mahatma Gandhis.  I am talking about the real world.
